title: 106_hr4300
content: The Act titled "Persian Gulf Security Cost Fairness Act" emphasizes that oil-producing countries reliant on US military protection during the Persian Gulf conflict should share responsibility for their security. The Gulf Cooperation Council countries are urged to contribute more towards their own security based on their economic capability. The Act titled "Persian Gulf Security Cost Fairness Act" aims to increase burden-sharing by countries in the Persian Gulf region benefiting from US military presence. The President aims to have Persian Gulf countries receiving US military protection increase financial contributions to cover nonpersonnel costs by 75% by September 30, 2003. This is part of the Persian Gulf Security Cost Fairness Act to promote burden-sharing. The Persian Gulf Security Cost Fairness Act requires countries receiving US military protection to increase their defense and foreign assistance budgets by 10 percent or to a level comparable to the United States by September 30, 2001. This includes increasing military assets and resources contributed to support the alliance. The Persian Gulf Security Cost Fairness Act requires countries to increase military contributions in the region. SEC. 4. AUTHORITIES TO ENCOURAGE ACTIONS BY UNITED STATES ALLIES. The President may take various measures authorized by law in response to a country's failure to undertake certain actions, including reducing military personnel in the Persian Gulf, imposing fees on countries hosting US forces, modifying security agreements, and reducing bilateral assistance. The President may take various measures authorized by law in response to a country's failure to undertake certain actions, including reducing military personnel in the Persian Gulf, imposing fees on countries hosting US forces, modifying security agreements, and reducing bilateral assistance appropriated for that country. Take any other action the President determines to be appropriate as authorized by law. SEC. 5. REPORT ON PROGRESS IN INCREASING ALLIED BURDENSHARING. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress by March 1, 2001, detailing steps taken by other countries and the President to achieve burden-sharing actions, differences in funding allocated by other countries, and expected budgetary savings for the United States. SEC. 6. REVIEW AND REPORT ON NATIONAL SECURITY BASES FOR FORWARD DEPLOYMENT AND BURDENSHARING RELATIONSHIPS. The President will review the status of US Armed Forces stationed outside the country, focusing on agreements with allies, national security interests, stationing costs, and alternative deployment options. The President will review the costs, force structure configurations, financial contributions, and stationing costs associated with alternative deployment options for US Armed Forces stationed outside the country. The President will review the annual expenditures of the United States and its allies in the Persian Gulf region on national defense, including the relative percentages of each country's gross domestic product. A report on this review must be submitted to Congress by March 1, 2001, in classified and unclassified form.
